Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hmmm, that's not what we want, is it? Today's digital cameras do a lot for us, but there's no replacement for the human eye. It's important to learn how cameras work with light to create an image, that way we'll know what's going on when it's time to capture a moment. There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. If we make the aperture big, we'll have more light, true, but the sharpness of your photo will decrease very quickly from your focus point, backward and forward. This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. For portraits, it can be nice to have a sharp figure separate from a somewhat blurry background so I would suggest a large aperture. Aperture is measured in f-stops. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. The shutter acts like a curtain that covers the sensor, and it only opens when you release the shutter button. If we want less light, we open the shutter for a shorter time. If we want more light, we open it for a longer time, but we run the risk of getting a motion-blurred picture. The speed is measured in seconds and fractions of seconds. For shooting sports or anything with a lot of movement, we'll need faster speeds. For taking awesome night landscapes, longer exposures will be better, but we'll need a tripod to steady the shot and prevent motion blur. Another cool thing we can do with light exposures is light painting, drawing in the dark with a torch or the light of a cell phone. Lastly, ISO sensitivity controls how sensitive the sensor is to light. If we use low sensitivity, we'll need more light to register a photo. With a higher sensitivity, we'll be able to get a picture with less available light. 100 ISO is a low sensitivity, while 6400 ISO is a high one. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. Good thing we have something to tell us if we're getting the correct amount of light to get a good exposure, the light meter. Sound good to you? Now it's time to get out there and practice taking pictures under different conditions, so you know what to do any time you want to take the best picture.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many variables are we able to change in a manual camera for getting the right exposure?
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary limitation of digital cameras compared to the human eye? Options: A. The inability to capture fast-moving subjects, B. The lack of ability to zoom in on distant objects, C. There's no replacement for the human eye, D. The inability to capture low-light images Correct Option: C
Question 2: What are the three variables that determine the correct exposure in a camera? Options: A. Aperture, shutter speed, and ISO, B. Aperture, shutter speed, and focus, C. Aperture, shutter speed, and exposure, D. Aperture, shutter speed, and sensitivity Correct Option: A
Question 3: What happens to the depth of field when the aperture is made larger? Options: A. It increases, B. It decreases, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes undefined Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary benefit of using a large aperture for portraits? Options: A. To capture a deep depth of field, B. To capture a shallow depth of field, C. To capture a wide-angle view, D. To capture a high level of detail Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the purpose of using a tripod when taking a long exposure shot? Options: A. To increase the ISO sensitivity, B. To decrease the shutter speed, C. To prevent motion blur, D. To capture a wider angle of view Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of increasing the ISO sensitivity on the image quality? Options: A. It improves the image quality, B. It has no effect on the image quality, C. It decreases the image quality, D. It increases the noise in the image Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary benefit of using light painting? Options: A. To capture a wide-angle view, B. To capture a high level of detail, C. To create a unique and artistic effect, D. To increase the ISO sensitivity Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the role of the light meter in determining the correct exposure? Options: A. To measure the aperture, B. To measure the shutter speed, C. To measure the ISO sensitivity, D. To indicate if the correct amount of light is being used Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary limitation of using a high ISO sensitivity? Options: A. It increases the noise in the image, B. It decreases the image quality, C. It has no effect on the image quality, D. It increases the shutter speed Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the recommended approach for taking awesome night landscapes? Options: A. A fast shutter speed, B. A slow shutter speed, C. A tripod to steady the shot, D. A wide-angle lens Correct Option: C
Question 11: How is the aperture measured? Options: A. In seconds and fractions of seconds, B. In f-stops, C. In ISO sensitivity, D. In shutter speed Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the effect of using a small aperture on the depth of field? Options: A. It decreases, B. It increases, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes undefined Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the purpose of using a shorter shutter speed? Options: A. To capture a wider angle of view, B. To capture a high level of detail, C. To get more light, D. To prevent motion blur Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the primary benefit of using a low ISO sensitivity? Options: A. It requires more light, B. It increases the noise in the image, C. It decreases the image quality, D. It has no effect on the image quality Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the relationship between aperture and depth of field? Options: A. A large aperture increases depth of field, B. A small aperture increases depth of field, C. A large aperture decreases depth of field, D. A small aperture decreases depth of field Correct Option: C
Question 16: What is the effect of increasing the shutter speed on the image? Options: A. It increases the noise in the image, B. It decreases the noise in the image, C. It has no effect on the noise in the image, D. It increases the motion blur in the image Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not directly ask how many variables can be changed in a manual camera, it does identify the three variables that determine the correct exposure in a camera, which aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ. The options provided in Question 2 also correspond to the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ, which is 3 variables (aperture, shutter speed, and ISO).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hmmm, that's not what we want, is it? Today's digital cameras do a lot for us, but there's no replacement for the human eye. It's important to learn how cameras work with light to create an image, that way we'll know what's going on when it's time to capture a moment. There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. If we make the aperture big, we'll have more light, true, but the sharpness of your photo will decrease very quickly from your focus point, backward and forward. This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. For portraits, it can be nice to have a sharp figure separate from a somewhat blurry background so I would suggest a large aperture. Aperture is measured in f-stops. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. The shutter acts like a curtain that covers the sensor, and it only opens when you release the shutter button. If we want less light, we open the shutter for a shorter time. If we want more light, we open it for a longer time, but we run the risk of getting a motion-blurred picture. The speed is measured in seconds and fractions of seconds. For shooting sports or anything with a lot of movement, we'll need faster speeds. For taking awesome night landscapes, longer exposures will be better, but we'll need a tripod to steady the shot and prevent motion blur. Another cool thing we can do with light exposures is light painting, drawing in the dark with a torch or the light of a cell phone. Lastly, ISO sensitivity controls how sensitive the sensor is to light. If we use low sensitivity, we'll need more light to register a photo. With a higher sensitivity, we'll be able to get a picture with less available light. 100 ISO is a low sensitivity, while 6400 ISO is a high one. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. Good thing we have something to tell us if we're getting the correct amount of light to get a good exposure, the light meter. Sound good to you? Now it's time to get out there and practice taking pictures under different conditions, so you know what to do any time you want to take the best picture.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: With a very small aperture we will get
Options: A. Shallow depth of field, B. Deep depth of field
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3

**Transcript**:

This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. **Transcript**:

There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hmmm, that's not what we want, is it? Today's digital cameras do a lot for us, but there's no replacement for the human eye. It's important to learn how cameras work with light to create an image, that way we'll know what's going on when it's time to capture a moment. There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. If we make the aperture big, we'll have more light, true, but the sharpness of your photo will decrease very quickly from your focus point, backward and forward. This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. For portraits, it can be nice to have a sharp figure separate from a somewhat blurry background so I would suggest a large aperture. Aperture is measured in f-stops. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. The shutter acts like a curtain that covers the sensor, and it only opens when you release the shutter button. If we want less light, we open the shutter for a shorter time. If we want more light, we open it for a longer time, but we run the risk of getting a motion-blurred picture. The speed is measured in seconds and fractions of seconds. For shooting sports or anything with a lot of movement, we'll need faster speeds. For taking awesome night landscapes, longer exposures will be better, but we'll need a tripod to steady the shot and prevent motion blur. Another cool thing we can do with light exposures is light painting, drawing in the dark with a torch or the light of a cell phone. Lastly, ISO sensitivity controls how sensitive the sensor is to light. If we use low sensitivity, we'll need more light to register a photo. With a higher sensitivity, we'll be able to get a picture with less available light. 100 ISO is a low sensitivity, while 6400 ISO is a high one. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. Good thing we have something to tell us if we're getting the correct amount of light to get a good exposure, the light meter. Sound good to you? Now it's time to get out there and practice taking pictures under different conditions, so you know what to do any time you want to take the best picture.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: For shooting sport we should use
Options: A. Fast speeds, B. Slow speeds
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary limitation of digital cameras compared to the human eye? Options: A. The inability to capture fast-moving subjects, B. The lack of ability to zoom in on distant objects, C. There's no replacement for the human eye, D. The inability to capture low-light images Correct Option: C
Question 2: What are the three variables that determine the correct exposure in a camera? Options: A. Aperture, shutter speed, and ISO, B. Aperture, shutter speed, and focus, C. Aperture, shutter speed, and exposure, D. Aperture, shutter speed, and sensitivity Correct Option: A
Question 3: What happens to the depth of field when the aperture is made larger? Options: A. It increases, B. It decreases, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes undefined Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary benefit of using a large aperture for portraits? Options: A. To capture a deep depth of field, B. To capture a shallow depth of field, C. To capture a wide-angle view, D. To capture a high level of detail Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the purpose of using a tripod when taking a long exposure shot? Options: A. To increase the ISO sensitivity, B. To decrease the shutter speed, C. To prevent motion blur, D. To capture a wider angle of view Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of increasing the ISO sensitivity on the image quality? Options: A. It improves the image quality, B. It has no effect on the image quality, C. It decreases the image quality, D. It increases the noise in the image Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary benefit of using light painting? Options: A. To capture a wide-angle view, B. To capture a high level of detail, C. To create a unique and artistic effect, D. To increase the ISO sensitivity Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the role of the light meter in determining the correct exposure? Options: A. To measure the aperture, B. To measure the shutter speed, C. To measure the ISO sensitivity, D. To indicate if the correct amount of light is being used Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary limitation of using a high ISO sensitivity? Options: A. It increases the noise in the image, B. It decreases the image quality, C. It has no effect on the image quality, D. It increases the shutter speed Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the recommended approach for taking awesome night landscapes? Options: A. A fast shutter speed, B. A slow shutter speed, C. A tripod to steady the shot, D. A wide-angle lens Correct Option: C
Question 11: How is the aperture measured? Options: A. In seconds and fractions of seconds, B. In f-stops, C. In ISO sensitivity, D. In shutter speed Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the effect of using a small aperture on the depth of field? Options: A. It decreases, B. It increases, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes undefined Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the purpose of using a shorter shutter speed? Options: A. To capture a wider angle of view, B. To capture a high level of detail, C. To get more light, D. To prevent motion blur Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the primary benefit of using a low ISO sensitivity? Options: A. It requires more light, B. It increases the noise in the image, C. It decreases the image quality, D. It has no effect on the image quality Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the relationship between aperture and depth of field? Options: A. A large aperture increases depth of field, B. A small aperture increases depth of field, C. A large aperture decreases depth of field, D. A small aperture decreases depth of field Correct Option: C
Question 16: What is the effect of increasing the shutter speed on the image? Options: A. It increases the noise in the image, B. It decreases the noise in the image, C. It has no effect on the noise in the image, D. It increases the motion blur in the image Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hmmm, that's not what we want, is it? Today's digital cameras do a lot for us, but there's no replacement for the human eye. It's important to learn how cameras work with light to create an image, that way we'll know what's going on when it's time to capture a moment. There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. If we make the aperture big, we'll have more light, true, but the sharpness of your photo will decrease very quickly from your focus point, backward and forward. This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. For portraits, it can be nice to have a sharp figure separate from a somewhat blurry background so I would suggest a large aperture. Aperture is measured in f-stops. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. The shutter acts like a curtain that covers the sensor, and it only opens when you release the shutter button. If we want less light, we open the shutter for a shorter time. If we want more light, we open it for a longer time, but we run the risk of getting a motion-blurred picture. The speed is measured in seconds and fractions of seconds. For shooting sports or anything with a lot of movement, we'll need faster speeds. For taking awesome night landscapes, longer exposures will be better, but we'll need a tripod to steady the shot and prevent motion blur. Another cool thing we can do with light exposures is light painting, drawing in the dark with a torch or the light of a cell phone. Lastly, ISO sensitivity controls how sensitive the sensor is to light. If we use low sensitivity, we'll need more light to register a photo. With a higher sensitivity, we'll be able to get a picture with less available light. 100 ISO is a low sensitivity, while 6400 ISO is a high one. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. Good thing we have something to tell us if we're getting the correct amount of light to get a good exposure, the light meter. Sound good to you? Now it's time to get out there and practice taking pictures under different conditions, so you know what to do any time you want to take the best picture.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: ISO controls
Options: A. The aperture, B. The speed, C. The sensitivity
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Hmmm, that's not what we want, is it? Today's digital cameras do a lot for us, but there's no replacement for the human eye. It's important to learn how cameras work with light to create an image, that way we'll know what's going on when it's time to capture a moment. There are three variables that determine if you're getting the right amount of light for the correct exposure. With a manual camera, we're able to change any of the variable ourselves. Different settings can result in really different pictures. Let's look at the process together. First, see this here? This is the aperture. It's the hole that light passes through. If we make the aperture big, we'll have more light, true, but the sharpness of your photo will decrease very quickly from your focus point, backward and forward. This is what we call shallow depth of field. If we have a very small aperture, we'll have less light but a deeper depth of field. For portraits, it can be nice to have a sharp figure separate from a somewhat blurry background so I would suggest a large aperture. Aperture is measured in f-stops. This can get a little confusing because lower numbers mean bigger apertures and higher numbers mean smaller apertures. Next, there's shutter speed to think about. The shutter acts like a curtain that covers the sensor, and it only opens when you release the shutter button. If we want less light, we open the shutter for a shorter time. If we want more light, we open it for a longer time, but we run the risk of getting a motion-blurred picture. The speed is measured in seconds and fractions of seconds. For shooting sports or anything with a lot of movement, we'll need faster speeds. For taking awesome night landscapes, longer exposures will be better, but we'll need a tripod to steady the shot and prevent motion blur. Another cool thing we can do with light exposures is light painting, drawing in the dark with a torch or the light of a cell phone. Lastly, ISO sensitivity controls how sensitive the sensor is to light. If we use low sensitivity, we'll need more light to register a photo. With a higher sensitivity, we'll be able to get a picture with less available light. 100 ISO is a low sensitivity, while 6400 ISO is a high one. If we increase sensitivity, we'll be able to use faster speeds and smaller apertures, but we'll get noisier images. Good thing we have something to tell us if we're getting the correct amount of light to get a good exposure, the light meter. Sound good to you? Now it's time to get out there and practice taking pictures under different conditions, so you know what to do any time you want to take the best picture.

there right now and for us humans it's not quite a material that's already there it's virtual on the other hand we humans we live in a physical world it's rich it tastes good it feels good it smells good so the question is how do we get the stuff over from the digital into the physical that's my question if you look at the iPhone with its touch and there we with its body the activity you can see the tendency it's getting physical the question is what's next now I have three options that I would like to show you the first one is mass as humans we are sensitive to where an object in our hand is heavy so could we use that in mobile phones let me show you the weight shifting mobile it is a mobile phone shaped box that has an iron weight inside which we can move around and you can feel where it's heavy we shift the gravitational center of it for example we can augment digital content with physical mass so you move around the content on the display but you can also feel where it is just from the weight of the device another thing it's good for is navigation it can guide you around in a city it can tell you by its weight okay move right walk ahead make a left here and the good thing about that is you don't have to look at the device all the time you have your eyes free to see the city now mass is the first thing the second thing that's shape we're also sensitive to the shape of objects we have enhance so if I download an e-book and it has 20 pages well that could be thin right but it has 500 pages I want to feel that Harry Potter it's thick so let me show you the shape changing mobile again it's a mobile phone shaped box and this one can change its shape we can play with the shape itself for example it can be thin in your pocket which we of course want it to be but then if you hold in your hand it can lean towards you be thick it's like tapered to the downside to change the grasp we can adjust to that it's also useful if you want to put it down on your nightstand to watch a movie or use this alarm clock it stands it's fairly simple another thing is sometimes we watch things on the mobile phone they are bigger than the phone itself so in that case like here this map it's bigger than the phone screen the shape of the phone could tell you ok off the screen right here there was more content you can't see it but it's there and you can feel that because it's thicker at that edge shape is the second thing the third thing operates on a different level as humans we are we are social we are empathic and that's great wouldn't that be a way to make mobile phones more intuitive think of a hamster in the pocket I can feel it's doing all right I don't have to check it let me let me show you the living more bat phone ok so once again mobile phone shaped box but this one it has a breath and a heartbeat it feels very organic and you can tell it's relaxed right now oh now mr. Cole a new course new girlfriend maybe very exciting how do we calm it down hmm you give it a patch behind the ears and and everything is all right again so so that's very intuitive and that's what we want so what we have seen at three ways to make the digital grass cover for us and I think making it physical is a good way to do that what's behind that is a postulation namely that not humans should get much more technical in the future rather than that technology a bit more human [Applause] [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Humans are sensitive to an object's weight. In the weight-shifting mobile phone, how does the weight move around the device?
Options: A. The phone rotates from left to right, B. The gravitational center in the phone shifts, C. The phone expands in length and width, D. The phone vibrates to simulate weight gain
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
I am a PhD student and that means I have a question how can we make digital content grasp the ball because you see on the one hand there is the digital world and no question many things are happening there right now and for us humans it's not quite a material that's already there it's virtual on the other hand we humans we live in a physical world it's rich it tastes good it feels good it smells good so the question is how do we get the stuff over from the digital into the physical that's my question if you look at the iPhone with its touch and there we with its body the activity you can see the tendency it's getting physical the question is what's next now I have three options that I would like to show you the first one is mass as humans we are sensitive to where an object in our hand is heavy so could we use that in mobile phones let me show you the weight shifting mobile it is a mobile phone shaped box that has an iron weight inside which we can move around and you can feel where it's heavy we shift the gravitational center of it for example we can augment digital content with physical mass so you move around the content on the display but you can also feel where it is just from the weight of the device another thing it's good for is navigation it can guide you around in a city it can tell you by its weight okay move right walk ahead make a left here and the good thing about that is you don't have to look at the device all the time you have your eyes free to see the city now mass is the first thing the second thing that's shape we're also sensitive to the shape of objects we have enhance so if I download an e-book and it has 20 pages well that could be thin right but it has 500 pages I want to feel that Harry Potter it's thick so let me show you the shape nightstand to watch a movie or use this alarm clock it stands it's fairly simple another thing is sometimes we watch things on the mobile phone they are bigger than the phone itself so in that case **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can the weight-shifting mobile provide eyes-free navigation?
Options: A. The closer you are to your destination, the heavier the phone becomes, B. The phone pulses in different directions depending which direction you should go, so you can even navigate with it in your pocket, C. The phone’s weight shifts in the direction you should walk, so you don’t have to actually look at the device to know where to go, D. The phone's gravitational center pulls you towards your destination
Correct Option: C

Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Jessica Ruby Mysteries of vernacular: Sarcophagus, a stone coffin typically adorned with decorative carvings or inscriptions. The history of the word sarcophagus is so skin-crawlingly grotesque, it seems to come right out of a low-budget horror film. Rather than having
a B-movie origin, however, its roots can be traced back
to the early Roman Empire where the Greek word sarkophagus was used to describe the limestone that a coffin was made of, not the coffin itself. According to the Roman
scholar Pliny the Elder, citizens of the Empire believed that limestone from a quarry near Troy would dissolve flesh. For this reason, it was quite desireable in the construction of coffins. Though it's unclear
if the belief was widespread or even accurately reported by Pliny, what is certain is that sarkophagus came from the Greek words sark, meaning flesh, and phagein, a verb meaning to eat. From flesh-eating stone to stone coffin, it's a fitting etymology for the final resting
place of the deceased.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the Greek word sark mean?
Options: A. Flesh, B. Power, C. Limestone, D. To eat
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of a sarcophagus? Options: A. To serve as a symbol of wealth and status, B. To house the remains of the deceased, C. To preserve the body from decay, D. To protect the deceased from the elements Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the Roman scholar Pliny the Elder's claim about limestone from a quarry near Troy? Options: A. It was highly valuable, B. It was indestructible, C. It would dissolve flesh, D. D: It was said to have special properties Correct Option: C
Question 3: What are the Greek words that combine to form the word "sarcophagus"? Options: A. Sark and logia, B. Sark and phagein, C. Limestone and Troy, D. Flesh and stone Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did the early Roman Empire citizens believe the limestone from a quarry near Troy would affect the deceased? Options: A. It would preserve their flesh, B. It would protect them from harm, C. It would dissolve their flesh, D. It would have no effect Correct Option: C
Question 5: In what context is the term "sarcophagus" used in the transcript? Options: A. As a metaphor for a person's life, B. As a symbol of wealth and status, C. To describe a stone coffin in general, D. To describe a type of limestone Correct Option: C
Question 6: What would be an example of applying the knowledge of the word "sarcophagus" in a real-world scenario? Options: A. Creating a sculpture of a sarcophagus, B. Writing a short story about a person's journey to a sarcophagus, C. Describing a historical example of a stone coffin, D. Discussing the history of a modern-day funeral home Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the Greek word "sark" and the concept of flesh? Options: A. It is a synonym for body, B. It is a verb meaning to eat, C. It is a noun meaning flesh, D. It is a metaphor Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the etymology of the word "sarcophagus" relate to its modern meaning? Options: A. It is unrelated, B. It is a coincidence, C. It is a fitting description, D. It is a complete opposite Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the author's tone when discussing the etymology of the word "sarcophagus"? Options: A. Serious and objective, B. Humorous and lighthearted, C. Somber and reflective, D. Somewhat tongue-in-cheek Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the significance of the word "sarcophagus" in the context of the transcript? Options: A. It is a trivial fact, B. It is a fascinating piece of history, C. It is a symbol of wealth and status, D. It is a metaphor for life Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine this: You're fast asleep when all of a sudden you're awoken! And not by your alarm clock. Your eyes open, and there's a demon sitting on your chest, pinning you down. You try to open your mouth and scream, but no sound comes out. You try to get up and run away, but you realize that you
are completely immobilized. The demon is trying to suffocate you, but you can't fight back. You've awoken into your dream, and it's a nightmare. It sounds like a Stephen King movie, but it's actually a medical condition called sleep paralysis, and about half of the population has experienced this strange phenomenon at least once in their life. This panic-inducing episode of coming face-to-face with the creatures from your nightmares can last anywhere from seconds to minutes and may involve visual
or auditory hallucinations of an evil spirit or an out-of-body feeling
like you're floating. Some have even mistaken sleep paralysis for an encounter with a ghost or an alien abduction. In 1867, Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell was the first medical professional to study sleep paralysis. "The subject awakes to consciousness of his environment but is incapable of moving a muscle. Lying to all appearance, still asleep. He's really engaged
for a struggle for movement, fraught with acute mental distress. Could he but manage to stir, the spell would vanish instantly." Even though Dr. Mitchell was the first to observe patients in a state
of sleep paralysis, it's so common that nearly every culture throughout time has had some kind of paranormal explanation for it. In medieval Europe, you might
think that an incubus, a sex-hungry demon in male form, visited you in the night. In Scandinavia, the mare, a damned woman, is responsible for visiting sleepers and sitting on their rib cages. In Turkey, a jinn holds you down and tries to strangle you. In Thailand, Phi Am bruises
you while you sleep. In the southern United States, the hag comes for you. In Mexico, you could blame subirse el muerto,
the dead person, on you. In Greece, Mora sits upon your chest and tries to asphyxiate you. In Nepal, Khyaak the ghost resides under the staircase. It may be easier to blame sleep paralysis on evil spirits because what's actually
happening in your brain is much harder to explain. Modern scientists believe
that sleep paralysis is caused by an abnormal overlap of the REM, rapid eye movement, and waking stages of sleep. During a normal REM cycle, you're experiencing
a number of sensory stimuli in the form of a dream, and your brain is unconscious
and fully asleep. During your dream, special neurotransmitters are released, which paralyze almost all of your muscles. That's called REM atonia. It's what keeps you
from running in your bed when you're being chased in your dreams. During an episode of sleep paralysis, you're experiencing
normal components of REM. You're dreaming and your muscles
are paralyzed, only your brain is conscious
and wide awake. This is what causes you to imagine that you're having an encounter with a menacing presence. So this explains the hallucinations, but what about the feelings of panic, strangling, choking, chest pressure that so many people describe? Well during REM, the function that keeps you from acting out your dreams, REM atonia, also removes voluntary control of your breathing. Your breath becomes more shallow and rapid. You take in more carbon dioxide and experience a small
blockage of your airway. During a sleep paralysis episode, a combination of your body's fear response to a perceived attack by an evil creature and your brain being wide awake while your body is in an REM sleep state triggers a response for you
to take in more oxygen. That makes you gasp for air, but you can't because REM atonia has removed control of your breath. This struggle for air
while your body sleeps creates a perceived sensation of pressure on the chest or suffocation. While a few people experience sleep paralysis regularly and it may be linked to sleep disorders such as narcolepsy, many who experience
an episode of sleep paralysis do so infrequently, perhaps only once in a lifetime. So you can rest easy, knowing that an evil entity is not trying to haunt, possess, strangle, or suffocate you. Save that for the horror films!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists think sleep paralysis is caused by an overlap of what two stages of sleep?
Options: A. Slow-wave sleep and REM, B. REM and waking, C. REM and slow-wave sleep, D. Theta sleep and waking
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the medical condition described in the transcript where a person experiences a sense of being suffocated or attacked while asleep? Options: A. Narcolepsy, B. Sleep apnea, C. Insomnia, D. Sleep paralysis Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the estimated percentage of the population that has experienced sleep paralysis at least once in their life? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. About half Correct Option: D
Question 3: Who is credited with being the first medical professional to study sleep paralysis? Options: A. Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell, B. Dr. Sigmund Freud, C. Dr. William Cullen, D. Dr. Alfred Adler Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the primary cause of sleep paralysis? Options: A. An abnormal overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep, B. A virus or infection, C. A side effect of medication, D. A genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the term for the paralysis of muscles during REM sleep, which is responsible for the immobility experienced during sleep paralysis? Options: A. REM atonia, B. REM paralysis, C. Sleep paralysis, D. Muscle atonia Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what effect does REM atonia have on voluntary control of breathing during REM sleep? Options: A. It increases control of breathing, B. It decreases control of breathing, C. It has no effect on control of breathing, D. It removes voluntary control of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the explanation for the hallucinations experienced during sleep paralysis, according to the transcript? Options: A. The presence of an evil entity or spirit, B. The overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep, C. The release of neurotransmitters during REM sleep, D. The lack of oxygen to the brain Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the sensation that people often experience during sleep paralysis? Options: A. A feeling of floating or being out of body, B. A feeling of pressure on the chest or suffocation, C. A feeling of being attacked or threatened, D. A feeling of relaxation or calmness Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the relationship between sleep paralysis and sleep disorders such as narcolepsy, according to the transcript? Options: A. Sleep paralysis is a cause of narcolepsy, B. Sleep paralysis is a symptom of narcolepsy, C. Sleep paralysis is a separate condition from narcolepsy, D. Sleep paralysis may be linked to sleep disorders such as narcolepsy Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, how common is it for people to experience sleep paralysis regularly? Options: A. It is a rare occurrence for most people, B. It is a common occurrence for many people, C. It is a normal part of sleep, D. It is infrequently experienced by people Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the cause of sleep paralysis, and both have an option that mentions an overlap of REM and waking stages of sleep as the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine this: You're fast asleep when all of a sudden you're awoken! And not by your alarm clock. Your eyes open, and there's a demon sitting on your chest, pinning you down. You try to open your mouth and scream, but no sound comes out. You try to get up and run away, but you realize that you
are completely immobilized. The demon is trying to suffocate you, but you can't fight back. You've awoken into your dream, and it's a nightmare. It sounds like a Stephen King movie, but it's actually a medical condition called sleep paralysis, and about half of the population has experienced this strange phenomenon at least once in their life. This panic-inducing episode of coming face-to-face with the creatures from your nightmares can last anywhere from seconds to minutes and may involve visual
or auditory hallucinations of an evil spirit or an out-of-body feeling
like you're floating. Some have even mistaken sleep paralysis for an encounter with a ghost or an alien abduction. In 1867, Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell was the first medical professional to study sleep paralysis. "The subject awakes to consciousness of his environment but is incapable of moving a muscle. Lying to all appearance, still asleep. He's really engaged
for a struggle for movement, fraught with acute mental distress. Could he but manage to stir, the spell would vanish instantly." Even though Dr. Mitchell was the first to observe patients in a state
of sleep paralysis, it's so common that nearly every culture throughout time has had some kind of paranormal explanation for it. In medieval Europe, you might
think that an incubus, a sex-hungry demon in male form, visited you in the night. In Scandinavia, the mare, a damned woman, is responsible for visiting sleepers and sitting on their rib cages. In Turkey, a jinn holds you down and tries to strangle you. In Thailand, Phi Am bruises
you while you sleep. In the southern United States, the hag comes for you. In Mexico, you could blame subirse el muerto,
the dead person, on you. In Greece, Mora sits upon your chest and tries to asphyxiate you. In Nepal, Khyaak the ghost resides under the staircase. It may be easier to blame sleep paralysis on evil spirits because what's actually
happening in your brain is much harder to explain. Modern scientists believe
that sleep paralysis is caused by an abnormal overlap of the REM, rapid eye movement, and waking stages of sleep. During a normal REM cycle, you're experiencing
a number of sensory stimuli in the form of a dream, and your brain is unconscious
and fully asleep. During your dream, special neurotransmitters are released, which paralyze almost all of your muscles. That's called REM atonia. It's what keeps you
from running in your bed when you're being chased in your dreams. During an episode of sleep paralysis, you're experiencing
normal components of REM. You're dreaming and your muscles
are paralyzed, only your brain is conscious
and wide awake. This is what causes you to imagine that you're having an encounter with a menacing presence. So this explains the hallucinations, but what about the feelings of panic, strangling, choking, chest pressure that so many people describe? Well during REM, the function that keeps you from acting out your dreams, REM atonia, also removes voluntary control of your breathing. Your breath becomes more shallow and rapid. You take in more carbon dioxide and experience a small
blockage of your airway. During a sleep paralysis episode, a combination of your body's fear response to a perceived attack by an evil creature and your brain being wide awake while your body is in an REM sleep state triggers a response for you
to take in more oxygen. That makes you gasp for air, but you can't because REM atonia has removed control of your breath. This struggle for air
while your body sleeps creates a perceived sensation of pressure on the chest or suffocation. While a few people experience sleep paralysis regularly and it may be linked to sleep disorders such as narcolepsy, many who experience
an episode of sleep paralysis do so infrequently, perhaps only once in a lifetime. So you can rest easy, knowing that an evil entity is not trying to haunt, possess, strangle, or suffocate you. Save that for the horror films!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: During a normal dream, special neurotransmitters are released, which paralyze almost all of your muscles and keep you from acting out the movements in your dreams. What is this called?
Options: A. Sleep spindles, B. Tonic immobility, C. Melatonin arrest, D. REM atonia
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the medical condition described in the transcript where a person experiences a sense of being suffocated or attacked while asleep? Options: A. Narcolepsy, B. Sleep apnea, C. Insomnia, D. Sleep paralysis Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the estimated percentage of the population that has experienced sleep paralysis at least once in their life? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. About half Correct Option: D
Question 3: Who is credited with being the first medical professional to study sleep paralysis? Options: A. Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell, B. Dr. Sigmund Freud, C. Dr. William Cullen, D. Dr. Alfred Adler Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the primary cause of sleep paralysis? Options: A. An abnormal overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep, B. A virus or infection, C. A side effect of medication, D. A genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the term for the paralysis of muscles during REM sleep, which is responsible for the immobility experienced during sleep paralysis? Options: A. REM atonia, B. REM paralysis, C. Sleep paralysis, D. Muscle atonia Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what effect does REM atonia have on voluntary control of breathing during REM sleep? Options: A. It increases control of breathing, B. It decreases control of breathing, C. It has no effect on control of breathing, D. It removes voluntary control of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the explanation for the hallucinations experienced during sleep paralysis, according to the transcript? Options: A. The presence of an evil entity or spirit, B. The overlap of the REM and waking stages of sleep, C. The release of neurotransmitters during REM sleep, D. The lack of oxygen to the brain Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the sensation that people often experience during sleep paralysis? Options: A. A feeling of floating or being out of body, B. A feeling of pressure on the chest or suffocation, C. A feeling of being attacked or threatened, D. A feeling of relaxation or calmness Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the relationship between sleep paralysis and sleep disorders such as narcolepsy, according to the transcript? Options: A. Sleep paralysis is a cause of narcolepsy, B. Sleep paralysis is a symptom of narcolepsy, C. Sleep paralysis is a separate condition from narcolepsy, D. Sleep paralysis may be linked to sleep disorders such as narcolepsy Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, how common is it for people to experience sleep paralysis regularly? Options: A. It is a rare occurrence for most people, B. It is a common occurrence for many people, C. It is a normal part of sleep, D. It is infrequently experienced by people Correct Option: D

The options in Question 5 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with some variations in wording.

Correct Option: C

Correct Option: B

It is a common occurrence for many people, C. It is a normal part of sleep, D. It is infrequently experienced by people Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever heard the term, "tip of the iceberg"? You know that icebergs
are mostly underwater, their immense bulk hidden
beneath the water. But why is that so? Well, the density of pure ice is less than that of sea water. Usually only 1/9
of the volume of an iceberg is above the water. The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion. This has led to the expression, "tip of the iceberg." Here are some thing you might not know about the icy islands. The life of an iceberg begins many thousands of years before it reaches the ocean. Unlike sea ice or pack ice, which form when the ocean freezes, glaciers are made of fresh water. For thousands of years, these glaciers build
layer upon layer of ice, constantly compressing, moving, adding snow, compressing, and moving again as they inch along like a frozen river. It is the force of gravity that pulls them towards the sea, where a glacier may calve
off to become an iceberg or continue to spread up as an ice shelf or an ice tongue. Once an iceberg breaks away from the glacier or ice shelf, it will usually live
for three to six years, floating around, carried by the currents and tidal movements of the ocean. As it floats along, it is battered by waves, melts, and smashes into land and sometimes other icebergs. Some icebergs are so unstable that they have more dramatic ends, heaving up, collapsing, and sometimes even exploding. And as they fall apart, many icebergs make all sorts
of strange sounds. When a piece of iceberg melts, it makes a fizzing sound, called Bergie Seltzer. This sound is made when
the water-ice interface reaches compressed air
bubbles trapped in the ice. As this happens, each bubble bursts, making a popping sound. There are six official size
classifications for icebergs. The smallest icebergs are called growlers. They can be up the size of your car and are very dangerous for ships and boats because usually they sit
just at the waterline where they are not easy to spot. Next are the bergy bits - yes, that is their scientific name - which can be up to the size of your home. The other four sizes are small, medium, large, and very large. So just how big is a very large iceberg? Officially, any iceberg looming larger than 270 feet high above sea level and 670 feet long is considered very large. That's 27 stories of looming, blue ice. And how do icebergs get
that blue color anyways? When snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years, the weight of the snow forces the air bubbles out of the ice, creating pure ice with very
little air trapped inside. This compression is seen when the glacier calves, creating a blue iceberg. An iceberg that has not experienced as much compression and has a large amount
of air and surface edges reflects light as white. Although they form in far
northern or southern areas, icebergs can float thousands of miles. An iceberg from the Arctic floated as far south as Bermuda. Antarctic icebergs are mostly trapped in the Circumpolar Current, never giving them a chance to float north. However, they have been known to interrupt shipping lanes between Australia, South America, and South Africa. For all their travelling, many people think that these slabs of ice
are barren of life, but these seemingly sterile ice slabs also harbor their own complex ecosystems and they shape the ecosystems that they pass through. They become mobile, floating ecosystems. Even in the coldest seas, icebergs are always melting, at least a little bit. This melting has a major impact on the ocean around an iceberg. The fresh water from the berg creates a pool of fresh water that can extend a nautical
mile away from the iceberg. This water is colder
than the surrounding sea water, and the temperature variation
creates thermal currents in the vicinity of the iceberg. Life thrives on and around an iceberg. Young icefish hide in small
ice holes to avoid predators, while a variety of invertebrates, like jellyfish and siphonophores, congregate in the area. Many of them come to feed on krill, tiny shrimp-like creatures. Snow petrels nest on the icebergs and feed on the sea life nearby. Whales and seals and penguins
seem to like them too. And even now that you know all this, we're still at the tip of the iceberg. There are all sorts of things we don't know about icebergs. Perhaps you'll be
the one to see a little deeper.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the term “tip of the Iceberg” refer to?
Options: A. I way to say hello in the old days, B. The fact the the majority an icebergs mass is hidden under the surface of the water, C. A way of saying there is more to something than you can see, D. A game Arctic people play in winter
Correct Option: B

The density of pure ice is less than that of sea water., C. The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion., D. The force of gravity pulls them towards the sea. Correct Option: B

Question 4: What happens to the air bubbles in the ice when snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years? Options: A. The bubbles get trapped inside the ice., B. The bubbles get forced out of the ice., C. The bubbles remain the same., D. The bubbles disappear. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the impact of an iceberg's melting on the ocean around it? Options: A. It creates a pool of salt water that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg., B. It creates a pool of fresh water that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg., C. It has no impact on the ocean around it., D. It creates a whirlpool that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg. Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the scientific name for the bergy bits? Options: A. Small icebergs, B. Medium icebergs, C. Large icebergs, D. Bergy bits Correct Option: D
Question 7: If an iceberg is 27 stories of looming blue ice, what is its official size classification? Options: A. Small, B. Medium, C. Large, D. Very large Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main reason why icebergs become mobile, floating ecosystems? Options: A. They are constantly moving due to the wind., B. They are constantly melting due to the sun., C. They are constantly growing due to the snow., D. They are constantly changing due to the ocean currents. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the typical size of a growler? Options: A. Up to the size of a car, B. Up to the size of a house, C. Up to the size of a building, D. Up to the size of a mountain Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of the title "tip of the iceberg" in the context of the transcript? Options: A. It refers to the size of the iceberg., B. It refers to the color of the iceberg., C. It refers to the complexity of the iceberg's ecosystem., D. It refers to the fact that there is much more to learn about icebergs. Correct Option: D
Question 11: According to the transcript, what is the name of the current that icebergs are trapped in when they originate from the Antarctic? Options: A. Circumpolar Current, B. Antarctic Current, C. Southern Ocean Current, D. Global Current Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the typical lifespan of an iceberg in the ocean? Options: A. Less than one year, B. One to three years, C. Three to six years, D. More than six years Correct Option: C
Question 13: According to the transcript, what is the name of the sound made when a piece of iceberg melts and a bubble bursts? Options: A. Bergie Seltzer, B. Fizzing sound, C. Popping sound, D. Melting sound Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the impact of an iceberg's melting on the temperature of the surrounding water? Options: A. It increases the temperature of the surrounding water., B. It decreases the temperature of the surrounding water., C. It has no impact on the temperature of the surrounding water., D. It creates a temperature gradient in the surrounding water. Correct Option: B
Question 15: According to the transcript, what is the typical size of a bergy bit? Options: A. Up to the size of a car, B. Up to the size of a house, C. Up to the size of a building, D. Up to the size of a mountain Correct Option: B

Have you ever heard the term, "tip of the iceberg"? You know that icebergs
are mostly underwater, their immense bulk hidden
beneath the water. But why is that so? Well, the density of pure ice is less than that of sea water. Usually only 1/9

the water-ice interface reaches compressed air
bubbles trapped in the ice. As this happens, each bubble bursts, making a popping sound. There are six official size
classifications for icebergs. The smallest icebergs are called growlers. They can be up the size of your car and are very dangerous for ships and boats because usually they sit
just at the waterline where they are not easy to spot. Next are the bergy bits - yes, that is their scientific name - which can be up to the size of your home. that blue color anyways? When snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years, the weight of the snow forces the air bubbles out of the ice, creating pure ice with very
little air trapped inside. This compression is seen when the glacier calves, creating a blue iceberg. An iceberg that has not experienced as much compression and has a large amount
of air and surface edges reflects light as white. Although they form in far

the one to see a little deeper.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever heard the term, "tip of the iceberg"? You know that icebergs
are mostly underwater, their immense bulk hidden
beneath the water. But why is that so? Well, the density of pure ice is less than that of sea water. Usually only 1/9
of the volume of an iceberg is above the water. The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion. This has led to the expression, "tip of the iceberg." Here are some thing you might not know about the icy islands. The life of an iceberg begins many thousands of years before it reaches the ocean. Unlike sea ice or pack ice, which form when the ocean freezes, glaciers are made of fresh water. For thousands of years, these glaciers build
layer upon layer of ice, constantly compressing, moving, adding snow, compressing, and moving again as they inch along like a frozen river. It is the force of gravity that pulls them towards the sea, where a glacier may calve
off to become an iceberg or continue to spread up as an ice shelf or an ice tongue. Once an iceberg breaks away from the glacier or ice shelf, it will usually live
for three to six years, floating around, carried by the currents and tidal movements of the ocean. As it floats along, it is battered by waves, melts, and smashes into land and sometimes other icebergs. Some icebergs are so unstable that they have more dramatic ends, heaving up, collapsing, and sometimes even exploding. And as they fall apart, many icebergs make all sorts
of strange sounds. When a piece of iceberg melts, it makes a fizzing sound, called Bergie Seltzer. This sound is made when
the water-ice interface reaches compressed air
bubbles trapped in the ice. As this happens, each bubble bursts, making a popping sound. There are six official size
classifications for icebergs. The smallest icebergs are called growlers. They can be up the size of your car and are very dangerous for ships and boats because usually they sit
just at the waterline where they are not easy to spot. Next are the bergy bits - yes, that is their scientific name - which can be up to the size of your home. The other four sizes are small, medium, large, and very large. So just how big is a very large iceberg? Officially, any iceberg looming larger than 270 feet high above sea level and 670 feet long is considered very large. That's 27 stories of looming, blue ice. And how do icebergs get
that blue color anyways? When snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years, the weight of the snow forces the air bubbles out of the ice, creating pure ice with very
little air trapped inside. This compression is seen when the glacier calves, creating a blue iceberg. An iceberg that has not experienced as much compression and has a large amount
of air and surface edges reflects light as white. Although they form in far

seem to like them too. And even now that you know all this, we're still at the tip of the iceberg. There are all sorts of things we don't know about icebergs. Perhaps you'll be
the one to see a little deeper.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever heard the term, "tip of the iceberg"? You know that icebergs
are mostly underwater, their immense bulk hidden
beneath the water. But why is that so? Well, the density of pure ice is less than that of sea water. Usually only 1/9
of the volume of an iceberg is above the water. The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion. This has led to the expression, "tip of the iceberg." Here are some thing you might not know about the icy islands. The life of an iceberg begins many thousands of years before it reaches the ocean. Unlike sea ice or pack ice, which form when the ocean freezes, glaciers are made of fresh water. For thousands of years, these glaciers build
layer upon layer of ice, constantly compressing, moving, adding snow, compressing, and moving again as they inch along like a frozen river. It is the force of gravity that pulls them towards the sea, where a glacier may calve
off to become an iceberg or continue to spread up as an ice shelf or an ice tongue. Once an iceberg breaks away from the glacier or ice shelf, it will usually live
for three to six years, floating around, carried by the currents and tidal movements of the ocean. As it floats along, it is battered by waves, melts, and smashes into land and sometimes other icebergs. Some icebergs are so unstable that they have more dramatic ends, heaving up, collapsing, and sometimes even exploding. And as they fall apart, many icebergs make all sorts
of strange sounds. When a piece of iceberg melts, it makes a fizzing sound, called Bergie Seltzer. This sound is made when
the water-ice interface reaches compressed air
bubbles trapped in the ice. As this happens, each bubble bursts, making a popping sound. There are six official size
classifications for icebergs. The smallest icebergs are called growlers. They can be up the size of your car and are very dangerous for ships and boats because usually they sit
just at the waterline where they are not easy to spot. Next are the bergy bits - yes, that is their scientific name - which can be up to the size of your home. The other four sizes are small, medium, large, and very large. So just how big is a very large iceberg? Officially, any iceberg looming larger than 270 feet high above sea level and 670 feet long is considered very large. That's 27 stories of looming, blue ice. And how do icebergs get
that blue color anyways? When snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years, the weight of the snow forces the air bubbles out of the ice, creating pure ice with very
little air trapped inside. This compression is seen when the glacier calves, creating a blue iceberg. An iceberg that has not experienced as much compression and has a large amount
of air and surface edges reflects light as white. Although they form in far
northern or southern areas, icebergs can float thousands of miles. An iceberg from the Arctic floated as far south as Bermuda. Antarctic icebergs are mostly trapped in the Circumpolar Current, never giving them a chance to float north. However, they have been known to interrupt shipping lanes between Australia, South America, and South Africa. For all their travelling, many people think that these slabs of ice
are barren of life, but these seemingly sterile ice slabs also harbor their own complex ecosystems and they shape the ecosystems that they pass through. They become mobile, floating ecosystems. Even in the coldest seas, icebergs are always melting, at least a little bit. This melting has a major impact on the ocean around an iceberg. The fresh water from the berg creates a pool of fresh water that can extend a nautical
mile away from the iceberg. This water is colder
than the surrounding sea water, and the temperature variation
creates thermal currents in the vicinity of the iceberg. Life thrives on and around an iceberg. Young icefish hide in small
ice holes to avoid predators, while a variety of invertebrates, like jellyfish and siphonophores, congregate in the area. Many of them come to feed on krill, tiny shrimp-like creatures. Snow petrels nest on the icebergs and feed on the sea life nearby. Whales and seals and penguins
seem to like them too. And even now that you know all this, we're still at the tip of the iceberg. There are all sorts of things we don't know about icebergs. Perhaps you'll be
the one to see a little deeper.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long will an average iceberg last floating around before it melts?
Options: A. 1-2 days, B. A thousand years, C. 3-6 years, D. 36 years
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why icebergs are mostly underwater? Options: A. The density of pure ice is more than that of sea water., B. The density of pure ice is less than that of sea water., C. The shape of the underwater portion is difficult to discern by looking at the above-surface portion., D. The force of gravity pulls them towards the sea. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the name of the sound made when a piece of iceberg melts? Options: A. Bergie Seltzer, B. Fizzing sound, C. Popping sound, D. Melting sound Correct Option: A
Question 3: How long does an iceberg usually live for after breaking away from the glacier or ice shelf? Options: A. One to two years, B. Three to six years, C. Seven to ten years, D. Eleven to fifteen years Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to the air bubbles in the ice when snow on the glacier is compressed over many hundreds of years? Options: A. The bubbles get trapped inside the ice., B. The bubbles get forced out of the ice., C. The bubbles remain the same., D. The bubbles disappear. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the impact of an iceberg's melting on the ocean around it? Options: A. It creates a pool of salt water that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg., B. It creates a pool of fresh water that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg., C. It has no impact on the ocean around it., D. It creates a whirlpool that can extend a nautical mile away from the iceberg. Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the scientific name for the bergy bits? Options: A. Small icebergs, B. Medium icebergs, C. Large icebergs, D. Bergy bits Correct Option: D
Question 7: If an iceberg is 27 stories of looming blue ice, what is its official size classification? Options: A. Small, B. Medium, C. Large, D. Very large Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main reason why icebergs become mobile, floating ecosystems? Options: A. They are constantly moving due to the wind., B. They are constantly melting due to the sun., C. They are constantly growing due to the snow., D. They are constantly changing due to the ocean currents. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the typical size of a growler? Options: A. Up to the size of a car, B. Up to the size of a house, C. Up to the size of a building, D. Up to the size of a mountain Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of the title "tip of the iceberg" in the context of the transcript? Options: A. It refers to the size of the iceberg., B. It refers to the color of the iceberg., C. It refers to the complexity of the iceberg's ecosystem., D. It refers to the fact that there is much more to learn about icebergs. Correct Option: D
Question 11: According to the transcript, what is the name of the current that icebergs are trapped in when they originate from the Antarctic? Options: A. Circumpolar Current, B. Antarctic Current, C. Southern Ocean Current, D. Global Current Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the typical lifespan of an iceberg in the ocean? Options: A. Less than one year, B. One to three years, C. Three to six years, D. More than six years Correct Option: C
Question 13: According to the transcript, what is the name of the sound made when a piece of iceberg melts and a bubble bursts? Options: A. Bergie Seltzer, B. Fizzing sound, C. Popping sound, D. Melting sound Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the impact of an iceberg's melting on the temperature of the surrounding water? Options: A. It increases the temperature of the surrounding water., B. It decreases the temperature of the surrounding water., C. It has no impact on the temperature of the surrounding water., D. It creates a temperature gradient in the surrounding water. Correct Option: B
Question 15: According to the transcript, what is the typical size of a bergy bit? Options: A. Up to the size of a car, B. Up to the size of a house, C. Up to the size of a building, D. Up to the size of a mountain Correct Option: B
